denly extricate me from my seemingly insurmounta
ble difficulties; sometimes when nature overcome by
hunger sunk under the exhaustion a repast was
prepared for me in the desart that restored and
insprited me. The fare was indeed coarse, such as
the peasants of the country ate, but I may not doubt
that it was e set there by the sprits th spirits that
I invoked to aid me. Often when all was dry, the hea-
vens cloudless and I was parched by thirst, a slight
cloud would bedim the sky, shed the few drops that
